result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (5th or 6th) and Operating w/ PAC (5th or 6th). The defendant was found guilty of OWI (5th or 6th) and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (5th or 6th) was dismissed by the court.

  • Marshall Jon Buersken was found guilty of OWI (5th or 6th), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: - $1,200.00 fine/costs to be paid to the Clerk of Court's Office within 60 days or set up payment plan.  Failure to pay may result in a civil judgment.
- $250.00 DNA surcharge to be paid to the Clerk of Court's Office within 60 days or set up payment plan.  Failure to pay may result in a civil judgment.

- Subject to Good Time & Work Release.  Court finds Defendant has completed the first 48 hours.  
- Must report to jail by 7:00 p.m., on 5/26/2017.  
- May serve time in Washington County, MN as long as there is no cost to Polk County.  Must provide information to Polk County if reporting to Washington County.
**May serve time in Dakota County, MN as long as there is no cost to Polk County.  Must provide information to Polk County if reporting to Dakota County.**
***Report date extended to 6/14/17, by 7:00 p.m.***
Concurrent with: **Pierce County Case 15CF117**

- Defendant must install an Ignition Interlock Device (IID) in all vehicles registered in their name.  IID shall be installed prior to Defendant obtaining a valid driver's license or occupational license. However, the length of Ignition Interlock Device will begin when a valid driver's license or occupational license has been issued. (Call Department of Motor Vehicles with questions).
- Must complete an AODA assessment & comply with recommendations.

- Must provide a DNA sample.
- May not vote or hold public office until civil rights are restored.  Other civil rights may be lost until restored.    
- If not a U.S. Citizen, may face deportation or loss of other citizenship rights.
- May not possess or use firearms or body armor.
